H0.text: Cars are safer to drive when they use the clean‑burning fuel produced by converting plant material into fuel, a method discovered by a scientist.

H1.text: Farmers grow more plants, benefiting people when the scientist’s method turns plant material into a cleaner‑burning fuel that can be used in cars.

H2.text: The amount of air pollution is reduced when plant material is turned into clean‑burning fuel that can be used in cars, a method discovered by the scientist.

H3.text: The number of cars around the world increases as people turn plant material into fuel, thanks to the scientist’s discovery of a cleaner-burning fuel that can be used in cars.

A9.text: A National Geographic overview article (2007) puts the figures at 22% less CO2 emissions in production and use for corn ethanol compared to gasoline

A10.text: Fast growing species like switchgrass can be grown on land not suitable for other cash crops and yield high levels of ethanol per unit area

A11.text: Biodiesel produced from used cooking oil or other waste fat could reduce CO2 emissions by as much as 85%

A12.text: Pongamia grows on marginal land not fit for food crops and does not require nitrate fertilizers
